ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: We continued to build our clinical skills by learning new therapeutic approaches and broadened our understanding of available evidence-based treatment.
-An array of skills and techniques used in psychotherapy, including DBT, family therapy, and couples work

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: My only suggestion for improvement is that I think incorporating more role plays and practices into the class would be really helpful for learning new therapy techniques!

We had more time to practice our skills in class this semester, which was very helpful. The course moved extremely quickly through a lot of fairly dense material and it would have been nice to have more time on each approach, though I realize this is a real constraint. It would have also been nice to have video demos for all units.
The course was an excellent and thorough review of many of the skills utilized in therapy. The roleplays and video examples of these techniques were particularly helpful

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Highly recommended and crucial for anyone preparing for clinical practice
